{{disambig-two|the father of [[Ælfwine]]|son of Ælfwine|[[Eädwine (son of Ælfwine)|Eädwine]]}} {{anglosaxon infobox | name=Éadwine | image= | caption= | people=[[Wikipedia:Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] | pronun= | othernames= | titles= | position=Mariner | location=[[Wikipedia:England|England]] | affiliation= | language=[[Old English]] | birth=[[Wikipedia:9th century|9th century AD]] | birthlocation= | rule= | death=Fate unknown (set sail in about [[Seventh Age 878|878 AD]] but never returned) | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor= | house= | parentage=[[Óswine (grandfather of Ælfwine)|Óswine]] | siblings= | spouse= | children=[[Ælfwine]] | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed=[[Éarendel]] (ship) }} '''Éadwine''' was a [[Man]] living in the [[Wikipedia:Anglo-Saxon England|Anglo-Saxon England]] in the [[Wikipedia:9th century|9th century AD]]. He was the father of the famous seafarer [[Ælfwine]], the first mortal to find the [[Straight Road]] in thousands of years. == History == Éadwine was an experienced seaman, who often told stories of strange, faraway lands to his young son Ælfwine. However, around the year [[Seventh Age 878|878 AD]], when Ælfwine was still a child, Éadwine took his ship [[Éarendel]] out to the sea and never returned. Around the same time, Éadwine's wife fled to her kin in [[Wikipedia:Cornwall|West Wales]], taking their son with her.{{SD|69}}, p. 270 == Etymology == The name ''Éadwine'' is in [[Old English]] and consists of the elements ''ead'' ("wealth, fortune") + ''wine'' ("friend").{{webcite|website=Behind the Name|articlename=Edwin|articleurl=http://www.behindthename.com/name/edwin}} Its modern English cognate is '''''Edwin''''', seen in the name of [[Edwin Lowdham]], the father of [[Alwin Lowdham]], one of the main characters in [[The Notion Club Papers]].{{SD|66}}, p. 236 == Genealogy == {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | OSW |OSW=[[Óswine (grandfather of Ælfwine)|Óswine]]
''fl. [[wikipedia:9th century|9th century]]''}} {{familytree | |!| | |}} {{familytree | EAD | |EAD='''ÉADWINE'''
''fl. [[wikipedia:9th century|9th century]]''}} {{familytree | |!| | |}} {{familytree | AEL | |AEL=[[Ælfwine]]
''b. [[Seventh Age 869|869 AD]]''}} {{familytree/end}} == Other versions of the legendarium == According to the early [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', the father of Ælfwine was a man named [[Déor (father of Ælfwine)|Déor]].{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 313 In ''[[The Lost Road]]'', Éadwine wasn't the name of Ælfwine's father but rather that of [[Eädwine (son of Ælfwine)|his son]].{{LR|P1III3}}, p. 83 == See also == *[[Herendil]] *[[Amandil]] *[[Éomer#Etymology|Éomer ''Éadig'']] *[[Edwin Lowdham]] *[[Audoin Errol]] {{references}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eadwine}} [[Category:Anglo-Saxons]] [[Category:Characters from the later Ages]] [[Category:Mariners]] [[Category:The Notion Club Papers]] [[Category:Old English names]]
